Title.evidence: The EAGLE study aimed to develop and test whether an international, standardized quality improvement intervention could reduce anastomotic leaks.

Trial_Design.evidence: Clusters (hospital teams) were randomized to one of three arms with varied sequences of intervention/data collection by a derived stepped-wedge batch design (at least 18 hospital teams per batch).

Participants.evidence: Low- and middle-income country enrolment was encouraged.

Intervention.evidence: The internationally intended protocol, iteratively co-developed by a multistage Delphi process, comprised an online educational module introducing risk stratification, an intraoperative checklist, and harmonized surgical techniques.

Objective.evidence: The EAGLE study aimed to develop and test whether an international, standardized quality improvement intervention could reduce anastomotic leaks.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome (assessed by intention to treat) was anastomotic leak rate.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Clusters (hospital teams) were randomized to one of three arms.

Blinding.evidence: Patients were blinded to the study allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total 355 hospital teams registered, with 332 from 64 countries (39.2 per cent low and middle income) included in the final analysis.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The primary analysis included 3039 of the 3268 patients recruited (206 patients had no anastomosis and 23 were lost to follow-up).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Anastomotic leaks arising before and after the intervention in 10.1 and 9.6 per cent respectively (adjusted OR 0.87, 95 per cent c.i. 0.59 to 1.30; P = 0.498).
